user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_close_error:
```c
static void
connection_close_error (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *emsg)
{
  connection->stop_with_error = true;
  connection->discard_request = true;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (NULL != emsg)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              "%s\n",
              emsg);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) emsg; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  MHD_connection_close_ (connection,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_WITH_ERROR);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (NULL != emsg)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              "%s\n",
              emsg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The if-statement’s body is executed whenever emsg is non-NULL (and only compiled when HAVE_MESSAGES is defined), so it is reachable at runtime. The alternative branch for the case WHEN HAVE_MESSAGES is not defined is provided by the (void) emsg; line to avoid warnings. There is no code here that can never be executed under any possible build/runtime conditions, so Rule 2.1 is not violated.
